relation: Shows a dialog box with the most important command line switches.
Specifies the base file used in three way diffs. This is the common ancestor of the files being diffed, although it is not shown in a separate window. For two way diffs, this is the left file.
The name of the base file. This is shown in the view title instead of the file path. For three way diffs it is shown in a tooltip for the view title.
Specifies the theirs file used in three way diffs, displayed in the left pane.
The name of the theirs file. This is shown in the view title instead of the file path.
Specifies the mine file used in three way diffs, displayed in the right pane. For two way diffs, this is the right file.
The name of the mine file. This is shown in the view title instead of the file path.

Specifies the resulting merged file used in three way diffs. This is the file path where the result of the merge/conflict resolving is saved. If this is not set, then TortoiseMerge will ask the user where to save the result.
The name of the merged file. This is shown in the view title instead of the file path.
The path where a patch should be applied to. If you don't set this path, then TortoiseMerge will try to find the path itself to match the paths in the patch file, but that can take very long.
The name of the original file to patch. Used for the view title.
The name of the resulting patched file. Used for the view title.
The path to the patch/diff file to apply to a directory.
Forces TortoiseMerge to start with the one-way view instead of the view the user specified in the settings.
Switches the left and right view of the specified two files to diff.

Creates a unified diff file (patch file) of two files specified with /origfile:"path_to_original_file" and /modifiedfile:"path_to_modified_file". The target path is set with /outfile:"path_to_resulting_patchfile". If /outfile is not set, a file save dialog is shown so the user can choose the location to save the patch file. Note: If /createunifieddiff is set, all other parameters are ignored.
Specifies a line number to jump to after loading the files.
Prevents the file from being edited. That means the editing capabilities of TortoiseMerge are disabled.
textBeforeTable: Table B.1. List of available command line options /base:"c:\folder\my base file.txt"   Most switches require additional information like a path or some other string. In those cases, append an ':' to the switch and put the string/path after it. Example:    TortoiseMerge Command Line Switches TortoiseMerge can be started with command line parameters to avoid having to go through the Open dialog to select the files yourself. This is useful also if you want to use TortoiseMerge from another application. TortoiseMerge Command Line Switches Table of Contents Appendix B. Automating TortoiseMerge  Next   Prev  Appendix B. Automating TortoiseMerge
textAfterTable: You can also supply simple filenames on the command line for compatibility with other diff programs. In this simplified form the command line is  TortoiseMerge BaseFilePath MyFilePath [ TheirFilePath ] If two files are given they will be compared with each other. If three files are given, the first is taken as the BASE file, and the other two are compared with it in a three-way diff. Prev     Next Appendix A. keyboard shortcuts  Home  Glossary
